com.guy.log

Class Logger

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.guy.log.Logger

  • public class Logger
extends java.lang.Object

    The Logger class provides a thread-safe and configurable logging mechanism with the minimum of effort required by the developer using it. There should be a Logger instance per class using the framework, the owning class is set on the Logger instance so that package-class-method are reported correctly in the log file.

    The Logger is controlled by a properties file which must be called logger.properties and must reside on the classpath. The following properties are supported, please note these are case sensitive:

    logger.switch=on|off Master logging switch.
    logger.appendMode=on|off Controls whether logging is appended to an existing file, or overwrites it.
    logger.output=filename Full pathname to logfile (the date will be appended to this).
    logger.logLevel=level Log level(s) required, separated by one of the delimiters '|&+,.:;/'
    logger.timeFormat=level Time format of logged timestamp, in standard Java time format. Default: dd-MMM-yyyy HH:mm:ss.S
    logger.performanceThreshold=level Only log the call if the duration is greater than the specified threshold (in ms)
    logger.packageFilter=filter Only log the call if the method definition of the calling method begins with the specified filter(s). Separate filters with a ';'

     

     

     

     

     

     

     


    Supported log levels are:

    off No effect if other log levels specified, same as logger.switch=off.
    entryExit Method entry/exit logging.
    info Information logging.
    debug Debug logging.
    error Error logging for handled/recoverable errors.
    fatal Error logging for non-recoverable errors.
    stack Stack trace logging.
    performance Performance logging.
    full All of the above.

     

     

     

     

     

     

     

     

    An example logger.properties might be:

    logger.output=C:/dev/logs/app.log

    logger.switch=on

    logger.appendMode=on

    logger.performanceThreshold=200

    logger.logLevel=entryExit | debug | error | performance

    logger.packageFilter=com.comet.ui;com.comet.db.entity

     

    An example usage of the framework could be:

    class LoggerTest

    {

    private Logger log = new Logger(LoggerTest.class);

     

    public void run() throws Exception

    {

    log.entry();

     

    try {

    log.performanceStart("Trace call to service");

    // do something

    log.performanceEnd();

    }

    catch (Exception e) {

    log.error("Something bad happened.", e);

    throw e;

    }

    finally {

    log.exit();

    }

    }

    }

     

    Author:
    Guy Wilson

    • Constructor Detail

      • Logger

        public Logger()
        Default constructor. If this constructor is used, the user will have to explicitly set the owning class using the setOwningClass method.

      • Logger

        public Logger(java.lang.Class owningClass)
        Construct a Logger instance and associate it with the class using it. The owningClass is used to log the class name correctly.
        Parameters:
        owningClass -

      • Logger

        public Logger(java.lang.Object owner)
        Construct a Logger instance and associate it with the class using it. The owner is used to log the class name correctly.
        Parameters:
        owner -

    • Method Detail

      • getOwningClass

        public java.lang.Class getOwningClass()
        Query the owning class.
        Returns:
        The Class which has been set as the owner.

      • setOwningClass

        public void setOwningClass(java.lang.Class owningClass)
        Set or reset the owning class.
        Parameters:
        owningClass -

      • entry

        public void entry()
        Used for logging entry into a method. LOG_LEVEL_ENTRYEXIT must be set for logging from this method to appear in the log file.

      • exit

        public void exit()
        Used for logging exit from a method. LOG_LEVEL_ENTRYEXIT must be set for logging from this method to appear in the log file.

      • info

        public void info(java.lang.String msg)
        Used for general information logging. Controlled by the LOG_LEVEL_INFO tag.
        Parameters:
        msg - - The message to log.

      • debug

        public void debug(java.lang.String msg)
        Used for debug logging that isn't required all the time. Controlled by the LOG_LEVEL_DEBUG tag.
        Parameters:
        msg - - The message to log.

      • debug

        public void debug(java.io.Serializable o)
        Used for debug output of the given object in XML format. Output is controlled by the LOG_LEVEL_DEBUG tag. Please note that only classes which implement the serializable interface will serialise correctly into XML.
        Parameters:
        o - - The object to dump.

      • error

        public void error(java.lang.String msg)
        Used for logging of error conditions, controlled by the LOG_LEVEL_ERROR tag.
        Parameters:
        msg - - The message to log.

      • error

        public void error(java.lang.String msg,
         java.lang.Throwable th)
        Used for error logging when an exception has been caught, the contents of Throwable.getMessage() are appended to the log line. Controlled by the LOG_LEVEL_ERROR tag.
        Parameters:
        msg - - The message to log.
        th - - The Throwable to append the message from.

      • fatal

        public void fatal(java.lang.String msg,
         java.lang.Throwable th)
        Used for fatal error logging as opposed to logging of recoverable or handled errors. Controlled by the LOG_LEVEL_FATAL tag.
        Parameters:
        msg - - The message to log.
        th - - The Throwable to append the message from.

      • trace

        public void trace(java.lang.Throwable th)
        Used to log the full stack trace of the given Throwable exception. Controlled by the LOG_LEVEL_ERROR tag.
        Parameters:
        th - - The exception to log the stack trace of.

      • stack

        public void stack()
        Used for debugging to print the calling stack at the point at which the method is called. Controlled by the LOG_LEVEL_STACK tag.

      • performanceStart

        public void performanceStart(java.lang.String msg)
        Used to log the start of a performance trace. Controlled by the LOG_LEVEL_PERFORMANCE tag.
        Parameters:
        msg - - The message to display when tracing starts.

      • performanceEnd

        public void performanceEnd()
        Used to log the end of a performance trace, the duration in milliseconds between the call to performanceStart() and this method is displayed. Controlled by the LOG_LEVEL_PERFORMANCE tag.
